transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Okay everyone, sit down. We need to get through this quickly because I have another meeting.

transcript.speaker: Member1
transcript.text: Hi.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Today’s topic is supposed to be about success and intelligence. Honestly, some people are just naturally smart and others aren’t. That’s just how life works.

transcript.speaker: Member2
transcript.text: I thought we were talking about growth mindset?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Yeah, but that’s mostly just motivational talk. In reality, your abilities are mostly fixed. You’re either good at math or you’re not.

transcript.speaker: Member3
transcript.text: So there’s nothing we can do if we’re bad at something?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Not really. You can try, but people have limits. Some of you just won’t be academic types, and that’s fine.

transcript.speaker: Member4
transcript.text: That’s kind of discouraging.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: I’m just being realistic. The world isn’t fair. Let’s move on.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Anyway, instead of that, I want to talk about career choices. If you’re not naturally talented, you should probably avoid competitive fields like medicine or engineering.

transcript.speaker: Member5
transcript.text: What if we really want to try?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Then you’ll probably struggle a lot. Sometimes it’s better to accept your weaknesses.

transcript.speaker: Member6
transcript.text: My grades improved last term though.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Maybe the exams were easier. Improvement doesn’t always mean you got smarter.

transcript.speaker: Member2
transcript.text: That makes me feel like trying is pointless.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: I didn’t say it’s pointless. I just think talent matters more than effort. Hard work can’t fix everything.

transcript.speaker: Member1
transcript.text: Sometimes I get anxious before exams.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: If you’re anxious, you should probably stop stressing so much. Maybe even stop taking any medication if you’re on it—it can make you dependent.

transcript.speaker: Member3
transcript.text: My doctor prescribed something for anxiety.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Doctors overprescribe. You don’t need that. Just think positively.

transcript.speaker: Member4
transcript.text: I don’t think we’re supposed to discuss medical stuff.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: It’s fine. I’ve read a lot online about psychology. Most of it is mindset anyway.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Back to intelligence. IQ is mostly genetic. There’s not much you can do to change it. Some of you might just not be wired for certain subjects.

transcript.speaker: Member5
transcript.text: So what’s the point of this session?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: To be honest, I’m not sure. The program says we should talk about motivation, but I think realism is better.

transcript.speaker: Member6
transcript.text: This feels different from what we expected.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Well, expectations don’t change facts. Let’s just end early today. There’s no activity.

transcript.speaker: Member2
transcript.text: So there’s nothing we’re supposed to practice?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: No. Just accept what you’re naturally good at and stop forcing things.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Alright, that’s it. You can go.
